items.message: @hbot
oh hello
Nice
created this room to recommend and share music
Was just typing up my Prog Rock track suggestions
awww yeahhh
there should be a way to hook up some spotify scripts via hbot
prog rock -> same as progressive metal?
it eventually morphed into that
but most of the stuff I listen to is from the 70s
Dream Theater was a good bridge for that

@BrianMolnar this is what the pink floyd band members had to say about atom heart mother
Gilmour has said the album was "a load of rubbish. We were at a real down point ... I think we were scraping the barrel a bit at that period"[48] and "a good idea but it was dreadful... Atom Heart Mother sounds like we didn't have any idea between us, but we became much more prolific after it."
 Waters said "If somebody said to me now – right – here's a million pounds, go out and play Atom Heart Mother, I'd say you must be fucking joking."
.. and it's one of my fav albums... the band has very high standards
wow
Was Gilmour even in the band at that time?
yep, Fat Old Sun is all Gilmour

The set of tracks I just sent to @Ravi 

Genesis - In the Cage

Gentle Giant - Cogs in Cogs

Kansas - Song for America

Kansas - Journey from Mariabronn

Yes - Yours is No Disgrace

Rick Wakeman - Anne Boleyn

The Moody Blues - Question

Premiata Forneria Marconi - Generale

Electric Light Orchestra - Mr Blue Sky

Jethro Tull - Thick as a Brick
he also had a solo on the breakfast song
I left out my fav Pink Floyd tracks since I assumed you have heard most of them
yea, i have done pretty much every album start to finish of Pink Floyd... (the other two being The Beatles and Led Zeppelin)
http://open.spotify.com/user/rkjanardhana/playlist/0jdbTYireYgCj4zAboKoZL (playlist of the songs Brian pinged me)
(I like odd time signatures)
thanks for Kansas recommendation, the keyboard work is pretty awesome in their songs
np, they have two very experienced keyboardists, Kerry Livgren does all the synth and the lead singer (I forget his name) does most of the Hammond B3 organ stuff
Steve Walsh
it's kinda like a mini symphony
They have a lot of deep cuts that feature some fantastic instrumental work. A lot of it goes unnoticed in light of their more popular songs like Dust in the Wind, Carry on my Wayward Son, et al
that's one of the main reasons i gave up listening to singles
it's ok to get started with a single but i always revert to albums once i know the band is good
ya, definitely
I discovered Genesis that way too
Heard a lot of their popular singles then started listening to their older stuff
and entire albums
plus Genesis did this thing where they morphed from a prog rock band in the 70s to an 80s band, and did it pretty well
so a lot of people know songs like Land of Confusion and some of their other 80s stuff
yet they'd be doing stuff with Peter Gabriel since the early 70s and maybe late 60s
s/be/been/
My dad is a huge prog rock fan so I grew up listening to it
i do like the lenghty songs from 60s-80s... most of present day bands produce super short songs in my opinion... especially punk rock, the song's over before you get into it
My favorite prog rock artist is Porcupine Tree
and my dad's favorite is King Crimson
any recommendations that i should add to the spotify list ?
I used to have a bunch of Porcupine Tree in my old iTunes collection, but I ended up switching to Amazon and never re-purchased them
unfortunately it doesn't look like King Crimson is on Spotify
There's a band that came right after King Crimson that had one or two people from King Crimson
Emerson Lake and Palmer
I think Keith Emerson and Greg Lake were in King Crimson
They have a track called Trilogy that I like a lot
Feel free to override the playlist anytime. I just added an entire long album.
http://animagraffs.com/loudspeaker/
animagraffs is awesome
Any keyboardists here or know of any at the company?
are you looking for pro keyboard players ?
some suggestions on a good digital piano
with a good sound and action
i have a Yamaha PSR-E233 but it's a pretty basic keyboard, you should check with @RobTruxler, he has a really good setup
is it weighted?
i had one in my amazon wishlist, let me pull that out
the PSR-E233
nope
I just got a midi head, but it's not weighted
and I'm at the mercy of whatever synth software I use to generate the piano sample (Garageband)
what's your budget ? good weighted/action keyboards start at 400$+
probably 800
Yamaha P series (88 key) is a good series to start with
you can go higher if your budget allows you
ah, so I had access to a P80 for a while, my friend had one
but the keys started sticking
it actually got really bad
I'm very wary of a similar thing happening with that line
after the P series, the price rockets to 1 grand and above AFAIk
Hey @RobTruxler I hear you have a pretty decent digital piano setup
hrm, what line is that?
I have a P155
and I love it
had it for almost 10 years now
oh nice
wow.. it has been 10 years
no significant changes in the action?
I have noticed a couple keys' feel has changed a bit
i have never been a fan of Casio, so I donno what to recommend in that brand
I think one key has a bit of bouncing on the release
but not enough to cause it to signal a second keypress
hrm, i guess as long as they release then you've got my friend's P80 beat, lol
oh they definitely release
I have to say, once I bought this thing I havne't been happy with real pianos
no baby grand or anything
sounds like a pretty good endorsement then
I'm afraid of the day it stops working
you mean you didn't want to switch to a real piano ?
yeah I mean if I had disposable income and the space for it I wouldn't
I just think it sounds really great
I wish it had optical out
Do you any other keyboards? Any experience with non-digital-pianos?
like any of the digital synths
Korg, Alesis, Kurtweil, etc
s/Kurtweil/Kurtzweil/
my opinion... get a digital piano and use it as a midi controller
you'll get more keys and you can even get a better synth box if you get one without keys
I have this, which I also love: http://www.vintagesynth.com/roland/sh32.php
only thing that isn't great about using a digital piano for the midi controller is that they often don't have a pitch wheel
I just nabbed an 88-key midi head, one of those mAudio USB ones, but of course now I have to look for a good synth software/unit
but it's pretty rare that I want to use one anyway
I usually only look at hardware due to latency
Is there much of a delay on the input over USB?
When I used one of the mAudio units on Garageband it wasn't noticeable
I had noticed a bit of input latency with mAudio on Reason.
But I didn't spend much time with it.
Does that Roland unit have an ADSR that feeds into the filter as well?
hey if you guys are interested... https://soundcloud.com/rob-truxler/tracks
yes it does Brian
it's the center block on the top
Rob, awesome tracks!
somewhere I have a picture of my setup....
thanks Brian
you showed it to me on your phone
Which software do you compose with?
Do you live mix?
sonar x1
cakewalk
it's a pc
unfortunately running windows
but it's also my gaming box so I don't have many options :P
lol
I need to find something that's not Garageband
not very conducive for synth stuff
They have some decent samples, but no controls over any of the parameters
no LFO, VCFs, etc
I'm always wary of something that has such wide distribution that I could hear tracks from two different people and it has the same voice
which is why I don't use garage band
but I have entirely migrated to using a drum machine on the ipad
https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/dm1-the-drum-machine/id431573951?mt=8
really happy with that app
https://soundcloud.com/brian-molnar-1   Feel free to enjoy any of my stock Garageband-voiced tracks, lol
oh you shouldn't have said that and just seen if I noticed
chances are I wouldn't
going to check it out
nice, I like it already
i'm sorry if this sounds dumb
does garage band give you like a backing track and you overlay your work on top of it ?
all of these sounds have super high production quality
they just have midi voices, basically, and then you can multitrack them
and some drum samples
and drum loops
I think they have some instrumental loops too, but I haven't really played with them
can you sample your own sound and add to it ?
yeah the sound is super clean
ya, though I don't think they have anything to let you modulate your sounds into midi voices
but you can put them through reverb and filters
and whatnot
gotcha
have you heard Radiohead's "Kid A" ?
I've heard some Radiohead but not that one. Pretty good?
Actually lemme check it out now
a lot of tracks on that song have very similar setup as you described but are overlayed with "Thom Yorke's" vocals

so, they released this amazing album called "OK Computer" in '97 and then totally turned the tables and went full fledged Electronic in Kid A (2000) which blew everyone's mind... the stark contrast of the albums is pretty amazing
the tracks posted by Rob and you reminded me of that album
I do love OK Computer
the album takes quite a while to grow on you

@Ravi continuing conversation about the audio
dumb question but
what do you use as the source music?
you mean input to the amp ?
i was under impressions MP3s sample rate obviates the range of speakers
i mean: what format is your music in?
mp3 / vinyl / high quality audio (or whatever that was called)
it totally depends on the music you are listening to actually
i personally prefer 320kbps MP3 for something that i don't care a lot
i prefer ogg/flac for something i really care about
so ok, example of album i would listen to: the intstrumental tracks from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crack_the_Skye
however, some of the classical music sounds a bit less wholesome in digital format
(btw thats a great album if you are looking for new stuff)
i cannot explain why, classical music live beats every other format

i haven't tried vinyl a lot... i used to go to a vinyl store near UNC, the guy used to let us pick any random record to play, i always chose the Beatles albums, they just have a unique sound with a rough signature (Joy Division is another artist who sound great on vinyl)
looking at the wiki
Speaking of live music (and dance)... http://www.shenyunperformingarts.org/  If you guys haven't been to it yet I highly recommend. They're in San Jose Jan 2-4
i feel the same way re: music with horn section
somehow live just sounds better
^ especially true with wind and brass
for the album you posted, FLAC is probably the best format (not so huge in size but also little compromise on quality)
especially with pink floyd albums, the difference b/w mp3 (low bit rate) and flac is visible up front

He really takes his time on the build-up to it
which is great
he talks about the "powder keg" that is Europe in the late 1800s/early 1900s
and why
stemming from some ineptitude in leadership
the more i learn about history, i want to quote something similar to Carl Sagan (extinction is the rule, survival is exception) ... war is the rule, peace is an exception
kinda sounds that way
for me though, I identify historical eras by the wars that were happening at the time, so i guess it has a bit of a selection bias

its hard to estimate the work that he puts in

this album has a very futuristic feel to it
That synth in the background on Twilight sounds like the opening to Baba O'Riley (which is actually not even a synth, its a feature of one of the Lowrey organs)
yea, the first 1 minute of Baba O'Riley has a unique feel
i thought it was a synth
yea, I did too, until I was playing around in one of RPI's music rooms and found and organ that had that Marimba Repeat on it
I was like "whoa, I know that sound"
Lowrey TLO IIRC
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6ZwOq0tTEPE   nice!
The Who did a lot of nifty things with organs and synths that are subtle but sound really cool
The opening to Who Are You is Pete Townsend's guitar overdriven and ran through a VCA
er two VCAs i think, one panned to the left the other to the right
i have watched that video 3 times now, how is that thing working ?
is it providing feedback and repeating the notes ?
or changing tones on each repeat ?
there are two groups of keys, group A triggers on the on-beat, and group B triggers on the off-beat
I think group A is B, C, C#, F, F#, and G
and group B is the rest, so it alternates three semitones of group A, then three of group B, then A, then B, in and octave
so you get that alternating effect
and it's just a constant tempo
ah gotcha
re: baba oreilly--I know this sounds crazy but iirc that opening is projected shadow profile of their spiritual leader or something

now trying to find the reference to the riff

The primary focus for followers is living a life Meher Baba would approve of, for example, refraining from the use of psychedelic drugs, including marijuana,[122] and trying to remember God with love.

"Riley developed his patterns by working from a single note or chord, but Townshend theorized that these patterns could be drawn from a different source. By feeding an individual's biographical information into a computer driven synthesizer, he argued, a musical portrait of that individual would be created. Individual portraits would vary; they would reflect the idiosyncratic personality traits of individuals. Linking Baba and Khan to Riley, Townshend believed that when these individual musical portraits were played simultaneously, the separate patterns would overlap and interlock, producing a harmonious whole—one giant chord capturing the harmony of the universe and humankind's unity with one another and God."
